title: 4 Simple Steps To Begin Your Meditation Habit

data.content: And cement it for good
Everyone experiences the need for a breakthrough in their life at some point.
Personal or professional loss and new life challenges can prompt this craving for personal growth.

Sometimes, we can find ourselves overwhelmed by life-changing external circumstances. Other times, the ordinary passivity of our lives catches up with us, provoking us to seek more meaning in our lives.
We seek habits to help us improve our lives, but we feel too depleted and worn out to invest in ourselves.

The endless content around us, our emotions and feelings have a profound effect on our well-being. When we react to anything around us, we lose energy and over time, we end up feeling perpetually exhausted.
If you want to feel more in control over this continuous energy expenditure, a regular meditation habit is an excellent place to start.
Jeff Wiener, the CEO of LinkedIn uses a daily meditation practice to help carve out time to think, instead of always reacting
Billionaire tech entrepreneur, Marc Benioff attributes his beginner’s mindset of being open-minded and eager to his routine of meditation.
Tina Turner referred to meditation as spiritual life support, helping her deal with the isolation of being a young singer and later, with domestic abuse.
In The Untethered Soul, author Michael Singer parallels our life events to a TV show, writing:
Meditation is a fundamental step towards self-discovery.
It returns the focus that we have given to our external surroundings, back to us.

In a systematic review conducted by Johns Hopkins University, mindful meditation matched the effect of antidepressants in reducing symptoms of anxiety and depression. A study at UCLA found that meditators had better-preserved brains than non-meditators over 20 years.
If that daunts you, even a 2-week meditation course illustrated better memory and cognitive reasoning.
Personally, for me, meditation has made a life-changing impact on my well-being, helping me reflect, find control over my mind and improve my relationships.
The evidence is clear, so why do we find it so difficult to establish the cheapest habit for self-growth that needs no equipment?
Still, when we find a way to plough through our mind and meditate, we can access the benefits forever.
Decide on a method
The first thing you will need to decide is how you will meditate. The options include guided meditations through an app or silent meditation with a timer.
Having tried both, I am biased towards silent meditation.
Although it may seem insanely tricky to sit in silence with incessant thoughts, I feel that you see the benefits of meditation earlier than when guided.
Guided meditations are great for beginners, looking for an anchor for their thoughts. Apps such as Headspace or Calm provide an ideal starting point.
Once you become more comfortable, I do recommend switching to silent meditation.
Create a meditation routine
Next, you will need to recognise the best time to meditate. To be honest, I feel that the actual time of the day doesn’t matter. It should ideally be a time when you are least likely to be disturbed.
Tethering it to an aspect of your life, like meditating after breakfast or before sleep will make it more automated and effortless to maintain.
Find a spot in your home that is quiet and can be solely for meditation, allowing its association with slowing down and calm.
Assign a time limit for your meditation. I recommend starting with 5 minutes and progress in 2–5-minute increments.
Let your mind wander
Meditation has nothing to do with stopping your thoughts and everything to do with not reacting to them.
Sit upright, but you don’t have to. Focus on your breathing, the air coming through your nose, illuminating your whole with life, releasing the pressure as it goes out.
When you realise that you that your meditation practice is a safe place where your mind can wander, you will learn two things:
When I find the mind-clutter growing, I meditate to regain my power of reaction. I don’t meditate to reason with my thoughts; I simply watch them pass through me.
Allow yourself just to be.
Accept that not all benefits are immediate.
In the current pace of the world, we expect instant gratification and results from everything we do.
Although meditation will help you find calm and peace during its practice, the extension of mindfulness in other areas of life takes time.
Meditation is a summative practice that needs continuity. The benefits add on and establish themselves in small increments each time you practice.
As your confidence in facing your thoughts grows, you will start feeling more in control of what you think, eat, wear or consume in any other way.
Meditation is like a muscle. It will grow stronger each time you use but shrinks when you let go of it.
The full-proof way to achieve mindfulness is to be realistic in how long you want to meditation and not let go, for even a day.
On days when I can’t find my forty minutes for meditation, I settle for five.
Finally
Doubt and fear limit our ability to form productive habits.
A meditation routine will provide you with the influence on your mind that is needed to upgrade other habits with less resistance.
Being patient with yourself and staying accountable will help you make meditation a part of your life.
It is as straightforward or as difficult as you make it, but either way, it will be the best decision you make for yourself.
